docs.lead_paragraph: The inmate accused of strangling John J. Geoghan, the former priest who was a pedophile, was a ''highly aggressive,'' emotionally disturbed child who was placed in a state residential center at 8, according to records of his trial for a murder in 1988 that were released today. The inmate, Joseph L. Druce, 38, told his lawyer today that he had killed Mr. Geoghan to avenge his victims, the lawyer, John LaChance, said. Mr. LaChance said he was quite likely to pursue an insanity defense in the killing, which was carried out on Saturday in a protective custody unit that Mr. Druce shared with Mr. Geoghan at the Souza-Baranowski maximum-security prison in Shirley.

headline.main: Inmate in Priest Killing Has History of Emotional Problems

docs.abstract: Joseph L Druce, inmate accused of strangling former priest John J Geoghan, was described in court records from his 1988 trial for murder as 'highly aggressive,' emotionally disturbed child who had been placed in state residential center at age 8; Druce tells his lawyer, John LaChance, that he killed Geoghan to avenge victims of his sexual abuse; LaChance says he will pursue insanity defense for Druce; nearly 150 people say they were molested by Geoghan; how Geoghan and Druce, who has strong homophobic views, ended up in same unit in jail is focus of investigations by state police, Correction Dept and Worcester County district attorney's office (M)
docs.snippet: The inmate accused of strangling John J. Geoghan, the former priest who was a pedophile, was a ''highly aggressive,'' emotionally disturbed child who was placed in a state residential center at 8, according to records of his trial for a murder in...

docs.lead_paragraph: Isn't it enough that Lucia goes mad, stabs her betrothed, Arturo, to death in the bridal chamber because she cannot be with her brother's arch rival, Edgardo, then dies, causing Edgardo to kill himself? No. When City Opera opens its production of ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' on Sept. 13, the title character will also be six months pregnant.

headline.main: 168 Years Later, a New Night at This Opera

docs.abstract: Jennifer Welch-Babidge will be six months pregnant when she sings Lucia in New York City Opera production of Lucia di Lammermoor on Sept 13; Lucia will be performed as written; pregnancy is alluded to only visually; director James Robinson decides to highlight his leading lady's condition rather than try to hide it; Paul Kellogg, City Opera general and artistic director, says he supports innovation, howver risky; Welch-Babidge, who is making her City Opera debut, says she welcomes additional challenge; photo (M)

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Hesitantly and with little public debate, Russia has increased its restrictions on abortion for the first time in nearly half a century. Russia's abortion regulations remain permissive -- there are still no limits on abortions in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy -- but the new restrictions appear to reflect the first stirrings of a wider debate here over the morality of abortion, as well as the effect abortions are having on women's health and on the demographic future of Russia.

headline.main: After Decades, Russia Narrows Grounds for Abortions

docs.abstract: Russia increases its restrictions on abortion for first time in nearly half a century, reflecting first stirrings of wider debate over morality of abortion as well as effect abortions are having on women's health and country's declining population trend; regulations remain permissive, with no limits on abortions in first 12 weeks of pregnancy; collapse of Soviet Union and increased availability of contraceptives have already caused abortions to decline from high of 4.6 million in 1988 to 1.7 million in 2002; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Hesitantly and with little public debate, Russia has increased its restrictions on abortion for the first time in nearly half a century.    Russia's abortion regulations remain permissive -- there are still no limits on abortions in the first 12...

docs.lead_paragraph: About 30 years ago, when the women's movement was at its zenith, what you might call the birth movement experienced a quickening. The women who had just liberated themselves from constricting brassieres, as well as those impressed by the natural labor approach popular in Europe, abandoned hospital delivery rooms in favor of midwife-assisted deliveries at home or at a clinic made to feel like home. In New York, the home-but-not-home option was the Maternity Center Association Birth Center, which opened in 1975 on East 92nd Street. In 1996, the clinic was reborn and christened the Elizabeth Seton Birthing Center and moved to 14th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues in the Village, where it has since welcomed about 1,470 babies who have arrived on the floor, between the faded polka-dot sheets and through the U-shaped birthing stool, all without anesthesia. Their mothers, who include doctors and midwives and women of many economic strata, tend to rave about the clinic.

headline.main: A Birthing Center Falls Prey To Rising Insurance Costs

docs.abstract: Article on Elizabeth Seton Birthing Center on 14th Street, which began as Maternity Center Assn Birthing Center on East 92nd Street in 1975 and is closing as result of escalating malpractice insurance rates; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Getting Religion In 1999, the Newark Museum accepted a proposal from two artists, Ilene Steglitz of New Vernon and Betty McGeehan of Morristown, for a group show on religion. But before the show became a reality, Sept. 11 happened.
docs.abstract: Jersey Footlights column notes Art Explores Religion, group show at Newark Museum; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Getting Religion      In 1999, the Newark Museum accepted a proposal from two artists, Ilene Steglitz of New Vernon and Betty McGeehan of Morristown, for a group show on religion. But before the show became a reality, Sept. 11 happened.

docs.lead_paragraph: Somewhere in the world right now, a rerun of ''I Love Lucy'' is playing. So are remastered episodes of the original ''Star Trek.'' People are buying DVD collections of ''The Twilight Zone'' and ''Mission: Impossible''; watching or renting the film version of ''The Untouchables.'' People are reminiscing about ''Ben Casey'' and '''Mannix''; Eve Arden in ''Our Miss Brooks'' or Ann Sothern in ''Private Secretary'' -- even that ever-cuddly ''December Bride,'' Spring Byington. What would our mass media memories be without Desilu Productions? It's a fine time, then, for Bravo's documentary ''Desilu,'' which has its premiere Sunday night. We all know Lucille Ball was a comic wonder, and Stefan Kanfer's lively, well-researched biography ''Ball of Fire'' has just been published. Desi Arnaz is emerging from the accent and the extravagance (both musical and temperamental) that people loved condescending to. We're finally learning that he was a business wonder. We think more of female comics than we used to. We know more about Cuban music than we used to.
docs.abstract: Margo Jefferson reviews TV program Desilu, Bravo documentary about Desi Arnaz, Lucille Ball and Desilu Productions; photo (M)
